events.name: A Tale of Three Lightning Talks
events.description:
A Tale of Three Lightning Talks

Join the Detroit Google Developers Group (GDG) for an evening of three fine lightning talks (hence the title). Each speaker will get 15-20 minutes to present and at the end of the evening we will have a question and answer period.

The order of the presentations will be:

Lightning Talk No. 1

Mat Stollman will present on Behavior Driven Development (BDD) and testing Mobile Applications using the BDD style. In particular he will cover UI testing of mobile applications. There are many tools out there currently to UI test mobile applications and Mat has experimented with many of them. He will cover how he recently started using a testing tool called Cucumber to run automated acceptance tests on Android and iOS devices.

About Mat Stollman

Mat Stollman is a mobile software quality assurance analyst for Quicken Loans. He helps build Quicken Loans mobile testing infrostructure using and testing it out with various open source frameworks. He also likes cats.

Lightning Talk No. 2

Build a Gateway with Google OpenID APIs

Google offers many services and some of these (like Google Apps) are federated; that is, a user can use a non-Google account to log into Google Apps. On the flip side, can a Google account be used to log into non-Google services? The answer is yes, since Google is an OpenID identity provider.

This lightning talk describes how to federate Google identities with non-Google services. In particular, we will demo a prototype that gateways Google identity (based on OpenID 2.0) into the InCommon Federation (a SAML federation of higher ed institutions).

About Tom Scavo

Tom is a long-time developer, teacher, and general technologist (you know the type). An enterprise SAML technologist by trade, Tom is finally coming to appreciate the utility of lightweight APIs and the security technologies springing up around them.

Tom lives and works in Ann Arbor, Michigan. He is Operations Manager for the InCommon Federation (incommon.org), a trust federation of higher education institutions in the US. He loves to write, cycle, and enjoys films of all kinds.

Lightning Talk No. 3

Accessing Google API's with OAuth 2.0 Google has a wealth of information hidden behind its API's. Much of it requires user authentication, OAuth 2.0 is Google's preferred mechanism for authenticating users. This talk will focus on what OAuth 2 is, how it works, registering an app on the Google API console, Google's libraries for performing OAuth 2 authentication,  and some examples of working with Google API's. About Dave Turner Dave Turner loves to code, and has been doing it in some form since 1999. He is experienced in many areas of software design and development including;  database, web, desktop, automation processing and mobile devices.

MORE DETAILS:

THE HOW: We will be meeting at the Quicken Loans Chase Building Security Desk and will go up to the meeting room from there. The Security Desk for Quicken Loans is off the Northeast entrance of the Chase Building (closest to Campus Martius).

FOR PARKING: There is Visitor Parking available at the Compuware Parking Garage on Farmer Street for $5 after 6:00pm for the evening. 

PLEASE NOTE: Please register here for the event even if you are not certain you will be attending. We need to provide Security at Quicken Loans a list of potential attendees 48 hours prior to the meeting.

events.name: Effective Data Visualization with David Giard
events.description:
Effective Data Visualization

We spend much of our time collecting and analyzing data. That data is only useful if it can be displayed in a meaningful, understandable way.

Yale professor Edward Tufte presented many ideas on how to effectively present data to an audience or end user.

In this session, David Giard will explain some of Tufte's most important guidelines about data visualization and how you can apply those guidelines to your own data. You will learn what to include, what to remove, and what to avoid in your charts, graphs, maps and other images that represent data.

About David Giard

David Giard has been developing solutions using Microsoft technologies since 1993.  He is a Microsoft MVP; a member of the INETA Board of Directors; and a past President of the Great Lakes Area .Net User Group. David has presented at dozens of conferences and user groups around the Midwest.  He is a recovering certification addict and holds an MCTS, MCSD, MCSE, and MCDBA, as well as a BS and an MBA. He is the host and producer of the mildly popular online TV show Technology and Friends. He is the co-author of the Wrox book Real World .NET, C#, and Silverlight. You can read his latest thoughts at www.DavidGiard.com.  David lives in Michigan with his two sons.

 

MORE DETAILS:

THE HOW: We will be meeting at the Quicken Loans Chase Building Security Desk and will go up to the meeting room from there. The Security Desk for Quicken Loans is off the Northeast entrance of the Chase Building (closest to Campus Martius).

FOR PARKING: There is Visitor Parking available at the Compuware Parking Garage on Farmer Street for $5 after 6:00pm for the evening.

PLEASE NOTE: Please register here for the event even if you are not certain you will be attending. We need to provide Security at Quicken Loans a list of potential attendees 48 hours prior to the meeting.

events.name: A Fireside Chat with CyanogenMod
events.description:
The Detroit Google Developers Group is excited to host a fireside chat with a member of the CyanogenMod development team, Jef Oliver. Jef will answers questions on CyanogenMod and discuss CyanogenMod's overall development process.

"What is CyanogenMod?" you may ask.

CyanogenMod is an aftermarket firmware for a number of cell phones based on the open-source Android operating system. It offers features not found in the official Android based firmwares of vendors of these cell phones.

In short, CyanogenMod is a custom version of Android that users can load onto their Android phones. It provides all kinds of goodies not found in the stock Android operating system that ships with many phones. For Android phones that are heavily themed by their manufacturers (ie Samsung, HTC, Motorola), CyanogenMod provides a very clean stock Android experience with some extra features. CyanogenMod is one the best known and most widely used custom Android experiences out there. Check out the latest news and more details at http://cyanogenmod.org/

This meeting will be very informal with lots of audience participation as we discuss CyanogenMod with Jef Oliver (via video conference) and understand what it is and the effort required to develop such great software.

Bring any questions you have and be prepared to have your world expanded as Jef sheds some light on CyanogenMod. Dinner and prizes will be provided.

events.name: The Android Accessory Development Kit presented by Terry May
events.description:
The Android Accessory Development Kit by Terry May

The Android Accessory Development Kit (ADK) is a reference implementation for hardware manufacturers and hobbyists to use as a starting point for building accessories for Android. Each ADK release is provided with source code and hardware specifications to make the process of developing your own accessories easier. Google encourages the use of the ADK to create new and alternative hardware for Android.

Android accessories such as audio docking stations, exercise machines and medical equipment are some of the devices that can interface with Android devices using the ADK.

In this talk, Terry May will discuss the ADK and how he has used it in some of his projects as well as demonstrate how to use the the 2011 and 2012 versions of the ADK. Terry has recently been exploring how best to interface Android with the real world via the Android ADK or the Newer android.hardware.usb package. This is a unique opportunity to see demos of the Accessory Development kits from 2011/12 and the "usb-serial-for-android" library.

About Terry May

Terry May is an infamous Detroit area Software Developer, autodidact and hacker.  He has done everything from small appliance repairman, television production assistant, WILX Graphic Designer, IT guy, assistant video editor, free lance 3D animator, WKBD Graphic Designer, flash guy and Multimedia Specialist.  He started hacking as a teenager on Commodore 64s and CB radios.

Terry is a polyglot programmer and ECMAScript virtuoso.  Today he works on Android Apps, Unity 3D and Augmented Reality projects for Detroit Labs.

MORE DETAILS:

THE HOW: PLEASE NOTE THE CHANGE IN LOCATION FROM THE QUICKEN LOANS QUBE BUILDING TO THE MADISON BUILDING IN DETROIT. We will be meeting at the Madison Building Security Desk and will go up to the meeting room from there.

NOTE ON THE WHEN: We will meet at 6:30pm, with food and beverages being served. The presentation will begin at 7:00pm.

FOR PARKING: There is Visitor Parking available at the Detroit Opera House on Broadway Street for $5 after 6:00pm for the evening.

events.name: Michigan Google Developer DevFest 2013

venue.name: The Madison Building in Downtown Detroit

events.description:
The Detroit GDG and the Ann Arbor GDG proudly present the Michigan Google Developer DevFest 2013.

What is a DevFest?

The Michigan Google Developers DevFest will consist of a one-day conference on Saturday, March 23, 2013 from 8:00am to 7:00pm where developers will meet and attend sessions related to Android. Confirmed topics at the moment include the new Android Maps API, Consuming Web Services from Android Applications, and Android and the Arduino controller. We will be adding more speakers and will announce them on this site in the near future.

Thanks to a sponsorship by Detroit Venture Partners (www.detroitventurepartners.com), we will have the 5th floor of the historic Madison Building for the day. The 5th floor includes a 120-seat auditorium for presentations as well as ample open space for working in small teams to code and learn.

 

So how exactly will the day proceed?

The DevFest will consist of a one-track series of sessions. Session leaders will have a presentation for each session as well as a exercise or tutorial for the attendees to work through after the presentation if they wish. The exercises and tutorials will be open ended enough to encourage attendees to get their feet wet by further examining the topic on their own. Overall, this event will cater to those who want to attend sessions and learn as well as to those who may want to gain some hands-on coding experience. All of the exercises and tutorials will be optional for those attendees who wish to participate. Attendees are encouraged to bring their development machines to hack on code as they wish.

The DevFest will officially start with introductions at 9:00am. Attendees who may have not coded in Android in a bit, or who wish to ensure their machines are ready for the DevFest sessions, will be able to arrive early, from 8:00am to 9:00am to work with volunteers to ensure their machines are up to snuff and ready for the day. Sessions will officially end around 5:00pm. Space at the Madison Building will be open till 7:00pm to allow attendees to further network and code as they wish.

 

What is included with the suggested donation?

We will use the suggested donation to provide breakfast and lunch for the day as well as refreshments. All of the funds collected will be used to make this day a success for all involved.

 

More information on sessions and speakers can be found at:

www.detroitgdgdevfest.com

events.name: The Google I/O Experience in a Nutshell.

venue.name: The Madison Building in Downtown Detroit

events.description:
The Google I/O Experience in a Nutshell

http://photos4.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/a/4/d/0/event_233982192.jpegGoogle I/O has become the must attend Google event of the year. In the past, Google has announce a slew of new products - both on the software side and hardware side. This year promises to be no different.

Come join Don Ward as he recounts the Google I/O conference week experience. Don will cover both his experience at the Google I/O conference. as well as the Google Developer Leaders Summit that will occur leading up to the Google I/O conference. The Google Developers Leaders Summit will be a 2 day event for Google Developer Group leaders held on the Google Campus in Mountain View, CA prior to I/O. With over 250 Leaders from around the world, this promises to be a good few days of knowledge sharing and planning for Google Groups.

Come and find out about these two fantastic conferences, and also hear about the latest Google gadgets that were given away at Google I/O.

 

Agenda for the evening:

6:15pm - Networking and Food and Refreshments

6:45pm - The Google I/O Experience by Don Ward

 

PLEASE NOTE: Unfortunately, we can not validate parking for this event. A map of where the Madison is and  locations to park around the Madison building can be found at goo.gl/LrU8X.  When you arrive at the Madison Building, let the security guard know you are there for the meeting and they will help you.

events.name: The Google Web Toolkit in Practice by Alex Boyd
events.description:
The Google Web Toolkit in Practice

The Google Web Toolkit (GWT) provides developers with a mechanism to build complex browser based web applications. GWT is unique in that [almost] all code is written in Java as opposed to browser supported JavaScript. By abstracting away the difficulties of cross browser quirks, XMLHttpRequests, and JavaScript expertise, GWT has proven to increase application performance, developer efficiency and code organization.

In this talk, Alex Boyd will explore how GWT works and it’s many advantages. Learn how iRule utilizes GWT, specifically, its versatility and performance. This presentation will also include a brief look at the history of GWT, it’s future, and other tools powered by iRule.

About Alex Boyd

After earning a B.S. in Computer Science from Michigan State University, Alex Boyd joined iRule in December 2011 as an Android developer.  Since then, Alex has worked on iOS, Google App Engine, Google Web Toolkit, and Python applications.  Previously, he was a Build & Software Improvement Engineer helping developers, engineers, and architects increase productivity and effectiveness.  In his spare time, Alex earned a M.S. in Software Engineering from the University of Michigan - Dearborn.

 

PLEASE NOTE:

Unfortunately, we can not validate parking for this event. Food and Drinks will be provided for this event.

Special thanks to Bizdom, Detroit Venture Partners, O'Reilly Media and Quicken Loans for their support of this meetup.
events.how_to_find_us: The meetup will take place on the 3rd floor in Bizdom's office. Let security at the front desk know you are there for the meeting and they will show you the way to the meeting..

events.name: Developer Patent Summit: Detroit

venue.name: The Madison Building in Downtown Detroit

events.description:
We’re talking about software patents, join us!

Do you have questions, concerns, or fears about patents, patent reform, or being stuck in patent lawsuits and litigation? The software patent system poses a significant challenge for developers. Patent trolls, product life cycles shorter than the patent process, and general uncertainty threatens to stifle innovation and growth in the app industry. The Application Developers Alliance is connecting experts with developers to discuss this critical issue. Join us along with industry leaders to enjoy a great conversation, food, beverages, and networking. Learn more and register for free below.

DATE: August 15th | FREE | 6pm
LOCATION: The M@dison | 1555 Broadway | Detroit, MI 48226
AGENDA:
6:00pm Welcome (registration, drinks, food, and mingling)
6:30-8:00pm Fireside chat followed by a panel-led conversation, and Q&A
8:00pm Enjoy beer, food, meet the panel, and network

Register and learn more at: http://devsbuild.it/devpatentsummit/detroit

events.name: Build and Test to Prosperity in Android

venue.name: The Madison Building in Downtown Detroit

events.description:
For our September meeting we will have two speakers presenting. The presentations are detailed below.

Testing - The Final Frontier in Android by Mat Stollman

BEHOLD! Testing! The final frontier of Android Application development. These are the voyages of the GDG. We will talk about what it takes to successfully test out your Android app to the point of perfection. Testing by means of Functional testing, Regression testing and Automation. We will dive into several automation frameworks to compliment your  development and testing methods. If you are lucky, we may even talk about the illusive unit testing (gasp). There may not be beer, but there will be a new found confidence in your apps! 

Mat Stollman is a Quality Assurance Analyst at Quicken Loans who works primarily on mobile apps. He is also likes cats.

Building with Gradle - Not you Parent's Build Script by Don Ward

With the introduction of Android Studio at Google I/O in May of this year, a new build system for Android using Gradle was introduced. Slowly fading from the landscape is the time honoured favourite Ant script. Gradle in many ways is more flexible, easier to develop with and more accessible to the Android developer. In Android Studio, Gradle is front and centre, and hooks have been added in Eclipse to switch to Gradle also. 

In this talk, we will discuss the background of Gradle, how Android leverages Gradle for it's own uses and some of the advantages of Gradle over Ant. There may not be dancing ladies, but you will be empowered to hack your build script with new found freedom.  

Don Ward is an Android developer at Quicken Loans in Detroit. He is an avid Google Tech fan and co-leader of the Detroit GDG.

PLEASE NOTE: Food and beverages will be provided for this meeting.

PLEASE NOTE: Unfortunately, we can not validate parking for this event. A map of where the Madison is and locations to park around the Madison building can be found at goo.gl/LrU8X. When you arrive at the Madison Building, let the security guard know you are there for the meeting and they will help you.

events.name: Build yourself a social network in 90 minutes by Nathan Dotz
events.description:
Build yourself a social network in 90 minutes by Nathan Dotz

The canonical introduction to any modern web framework is a heads-first dive into just how easy it is to create Yet Another Social Network with it. In this session, you'll get exactly that: a whirlwind tour of just how easy and – more importantly – fun, it is to create web applications in Play 2. Play's high productivity and developer-friendly toolchain will obliterate any preconceived notions you have about web development on the JVM. With effortless inclusion of technologies you love like CoffeeScript and LESS, all within the comfort of gloriously type-safe routing and asynchronous responses, you'll be so hooked you won't even realize you're writing in deliciously functional Scala!

About Nathan Dotz

Nathan is a software engineer at Detroit Labs, where miracles are performed on mobile devices. He is a founding member of the All Hands Active Hackerspace, which has been working steadfastly to awesomify the brains of creators for over 3 years. He’s an open-source contributor, an open-education advocate, and a functional programming fanboy.

PLEASE NOTE: Food and beverages will be provided for this meeting.

events.name: Android Performance - 5 Top Tips by Godfrey Nolan
events.description:
PLEASE NOTE: This meetup was rescheduled from Jan 28, 2014 to Feb 12, 2014 due to the cold weather.

Android Performance - Top 5 Tips

Android application development, like every other client side technology can suffer from basic performance issues. In this session we go through our top 5 performance tips which are as follows:

• Streamline your GUI

• Shrink your API

• Identify Memory Issues

• Profile your code

• Measuring Performance in the Field

Using a sample app in this class we look at what tools and techniques can be applied in each area and show how to identify areas of improvement for each tip. We'll also show how to use Calabash for before and after timings for each tip to keep us honest.

About Godfrey Nolan

Godfrey Nolan is founder and president of RIIS LLC a mobile development firm in the Detroit Metro area. He is also author of Android Best Practices (Apress), Decompiling Java (Apress) and Decompiling Android (Apress). Godfrey has spoken at several AnDevcon's as well as JavaOne, ASP-Connections, VSLive, Codemash, Code PaLOUsa, 1DevDay and many local Java and .Net user groups on a wide range of topics such as Continuous Integration, Executable Requirements and mobile security.

PLEASE NOTE:

The presentation will start shortly after 6:45pm with food and beverages arriving at 6:30pm.

Unfortunately, we can not validate parking for this event.

events.name: Dart Flight School - Code Lab
events.description:
Dart hit 1.0 and is now Flight Ready! Developer communities around the world are hosting Dart Flight School events during the month of February 2014. 

Learn Dart during this tech talk that the Detroit Google Developer Group will be hosting. 

This event will be a code lab! Be sure to bring your development machine and get ready to get some hands-on Dart code-writing experience.

Please look for a Detroit GDG member with a GDG sign in the lobby of the building to be escorted past security into the event. If you have issues, please call Don Ward at (313) 373 - 4399.

PLEASE NOTE: We can not validate parking for this meeting. There are various parking locations around the building with a secure one being the Compuware Parking Structure a 1140 Farmer St, Detroit, MI.

events.name: High Performance Computing with Dave Strenski
events.description:
High Performance Computing

Does High Performance Computing sound exciting and cool to you? Want to learn more about what it is and it's applications? Dave Strenski, from Cray Inc., has offered to tell our group about the exciting things happening in the realm of HPC and what Cray is doing to push the limits of this exciting field.

This presentation will give a brief history of HPC technologies, and dive into the details of HPC technologies that are popular today, including: parallel shared file systems, accelerators like FPGAs, GPGPUs, and many core processors, and also touch on how HPC is migrating into the Big Data market space with custom semantic database and Hadoop machines.

About Dave Strenski

Dave has degrees in Surveying, Civil and Mechanical Engineering from Michigan Tech <a>http://www.mtu.edu</a>;. Currently he works as an Applications Analyst for Cray Inc. http://www.cray.com, which designs and manufactures high performance computers. His publications include works in the areas of parallel computing, numerical consistency http://papers.sae.org/971520, genomic data searching algorithms <a>http://www.plantphysiol.org/content/138/3/1457</a>;, Field Programmable Gate Arrays tinyurl.com/fpga-ft-pt-2010, and was issued a patent [masked]) on a meshing algorithm for threaded fasteners. As a hobby, Dave plays with solar power and founded SolarYpsi.org which was feature in a Google Search video http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b6VtzqZiSEk which has been viewed by a ¼ million people.

About Cray

Cray started in the High Performance Computing (HPC) business back in 1972 http://www.cray.com/Assets/PDF/about/CrayTimeline.pdf with the Cray-1 system installed at Los Alamos National Laboratory. It boasted a world-record speed of 160 million floating-point operations per second (160 megaflops) and an 8 megabyte main memory. Today Cray continues to lead the HPC market and currently has the second fastest machine, Titan http://www.olcf.ornl.gov/titan, in the world with 27 petaflops (27,000,000,000,000 floating-point operations per second) installed at OakRidge National Laboratory.

PLEASE NOTE:

Doors will open at 6:30pm with the presentation starting around 7pm. Food and beverages will arrive at 6:30pm.

Unfortunately, we can not validate parking for this event.

events.name: The Michigan Google Developers DevFest 2014
events.description:
The Detroit and Ann Arbor Chapters of the Google Developers Group (GDG) are hosting a one day Google DevFest in Downtown Detroit. The DevFest will focus on two tracks - one on Android development and one on Google Web Technology. Checkout the website for all the details.

This event requires the purchase of a ticket for entry in order to help us cover the costs of the event. You must register via the EventBrite page in order to attend.

events.name: Start developing with Android Wear
events.description:
Recently Google announced a new version of Android called Android Wear that is designed for smart phones and other wearables. At the moment, there is a Preview SDK available for Android Wear. With the annual Google I/O conference just around the corner, there may be more announcements about Android Wear in the near future.

Come out and join the Detroit Google Developers Group on Monday, June 16, 2014 for an evening of learning about Android Wear and how to develop with it. We do not proclaim to be experts on Android Wear. We do however have materials and code labs from Google for Developer Groups to work together on to learn and develop for Android Wear.

We also have a few vouchers that we will be raffling off for a yet to be announced Google Wear device. Google has not disclosed to us what these devices may be and the vouchers can be redeemed after the Google I/O conference later this month. These vouchers may be good for a Google Watch, a Google Fitness Band, or even a Google Shoe Phone. We do not know, and that is part of the fun.

There are a few prerequisites you may want to look at before attending to get more out of the event. They are:

• Familiarity with the Java programming language

• Access to an Android phone or tablet for testing

• Pre-event: Sign up for the Developer Preview http://developer.android.com/wear/preview/signup.html. It takes up 24 hours to get approved.

• After registration, you should get a confirmation email that includes a link to the Android Wear Developer Preview support library and a link to opt-in to the Android Wear Preview app beta distribution in Google Play store.

• Android Wear DevByte playlist

• Join the +Android Wear Developers community: g.co/androidweardev

• Bring an Android phone or tablet to the event for testing your app.

PLEASE NOTE:

The presentation will start shortly after 6:45pm with food and beverages arriving at 6:30pm.

Unfortunately, we can not validate parking for this event.

events.name: Building web services using Google Go and MongoDB
events.description:
Building web services using Go and MongoDB

Go is a fantastic language in which to build web services.  It was developed at Google in 2007 and has found use in some of Google's internal systems as well as on Google App Engine. Initially an experimental project, it was created with the intention of creating a language with a syntax loosely derived from C, but adding some of the niceties of modern languages, such as garbage collection, variable-length arrays and a large standard library.

In this talk, Charles will discuss the basics of Go and its' strengths and weaknesses. After an introduction to the language, Charles will talk about JSON and its relationship with Go data structures. This will be followed up by connecting a MongoDB database for data persistence. Adding in some choice open-source packages the end result of the discussion will be the creation of a simple web service.

About Charles Redmond

Charles Redmond is a Software Engineer with Quicken Loans and a Go enthusiast. He recently presented at the Michigan Google Developer DevFest conference on the subject of the Go language.

PLEASE NOTE:

The presentation will start shortly after 6:45pm with food and beverages arriving at 6:30pm.

Unfortunately, we can not validate parking for this event.

events.name: Android Bluetooth 4.0: Talking to sensors and listening to beacons by Terry May
events.description:
Android Bluetooth 4.0: Talking to sensors and listening to beacons.

Blue Tooth Low Energy (BLE) is finally making it's way into newer Android devices. BLE has many uses and is going to get even better support in the upcoming Android L release. In this presentation we will observe temperature from a remote sensor, send data and demonstrate beacons. There will be plenty of detailed code and hardware demonstrations and hopefully lots of fun!

About Terry May

Terry May is a Detroit area Software Developer, autodidact and hacker. He has done everything from small appliance repairman, television production assistant, Graphic Designer, IT guy, assistant video editor, free lance 3D animator and Multimedia Specialist. He started hacking as a teenager on Commodore 64s and CB radios.

Terry is a polyglot programmer, electronics experimenter and amateur radio operator. Today he works on Android Apps and Hardware Prototypes for Detroit Labs.

PLEASE NOTE:

The presentation will start shortly after 6:45pm with food and beverages arriving at 6:30pm.

Unfortunately, we can not validate parking for this event.

events.name: Learn Polymer - Part 1
events.description:
Google Polymer

Google introduced Google Polymer a little over one year ago. Polymer is a library for creating Web Components, which are a set of W3C standards and upcoming browser APIs for defining your own custom HTML elements. 

Google’s using Polymer to bring its new “Material Design” look to the web. 

Join the Detroit Google Developers Group for a evening of learning Polymer and working through code labs on Polymer.

Please bring your own computer to work through examples with.

Food and beverages will be provided as well as some cool Google swag!

PLEASE NOTE: This will be the first meeting of two to discuss and learn Polymer.

events.name: Learn Polymer - Part 2
events.description:
Google Polymer

Google introduced Google Polymer a little over one year ago. Polymer is a library for creating Web Components, which are a set of W3C standards and upcoming browser APIs for defining your own custom HTML elements. 

Google’s using Polymer to bring its new “Material Design” look to the web. 

Join the Detroit Google Developers Group for a evening of learning Polymer and working through code labs on Polymer.

Please bring your own computer to work through examples with.

PLEASE NOTE: If you attended the first evening on Polymer, we will have a room where you can continue to learn about Polymer. If you did not attend the first evening on Polymer, we will also have a room where the material from the first evening will be covered.

Food and beverages will be provided as well as some cool Google swag!

events.name: Crossing the boundaries of Mobile App Development with Steven Hanus
events.description:
Crossing the boundaries of Mobile App Development

In this presentation, Steven Hanus will be demonstrating three apps that break the “boundaries” of conventional app development. He will demonstrate that you too, can make these same applications to impress your friends and family. The applications will focus mainly on Android and iOS with some discussion on Windows Phone as well.

About Steven Hanus

Steven Hanus is a mobile developer at Title Source in Detroit, MI specializing in Android development. He likes to learn anything and everything about software development as long as it is interesting. Whatever you do, don’t ask him to make your app for you - he won't.

events.name: The A-Z on Solar Power for Developers with Dave Strenski
events.description:
The A-Z on Solar Power for Developers with Dave Strenski

Solar power has been growing in this country at a tremendous rate over the past few years, and Ypsilanti is ahead of the curve in embracing it. Dave will explain the basics of photovoltaic power: how to install grid-tied systems, the economics of solar power in Michigan, and why you should consider a solar installation on your building. The talk will also cover the meter reading program Dave invented to read utility meters for essentially free, and strategies about how to read the new smart meters. If you're unable to attend this presentation, then check out Dave's TEDx talk about solar power at <http://youtu.be/Mx0pTz-Qc40>

About Dave Strenski

Dave has degrees in Surveying, Civil and Mechanical Engineering from Michigan Tech. Currently he works as an applications analyst for Cray Inc., which designs and manufactures high performance computing, storage, and data analytic systems. Dave started playing with solar power in 2005 when he founded SolarYpsi, a group of volunteers that design and install photovoltaic systems locally. Here is a video about SolarYpsi made by Google.<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b6VtzqZiSEk

PLEASE NOTE:

The presentation will start shortly after 6:45pm with food and beverages arriving at 6:30pm.

Unfortunately, we can not validate parking for this event.

events.name: Setting up a Lean Startup Online with David Stiebel
events.description:
Setting up a Lean Startup Online with David Stiebel

In this hands on presentation, David Stiebel is going to demonstrate a recent "app" he created for a friend who wanted to lean test her startup idea.

His friend wanted to start a unique "social" group-centric flower delivery service, and needed:

•  A way for new customers to signup, order flowers, and invite friends to join their group.

•  A way for invited friends to get notified, join the group, and order their own flowers

•  A way for her staff to manage new users, groups, emails to users + groups, and coordinate scheduling and delivery of flowers, etc.

In this presentation, David will discuss and demonstrate how he created a 1-page website, created new client signup and ordering forms, created automatic emails for clients, and set up the ability for client's to invite friends. David will also discuss how all of this is manageable by his friend's staff and is scalable long term. 

Using a mix of Google technology and best in breed tools - David will demonstrate how a startup can run very lean, be very hands on, and be very flexible. The best part is that most of these tools are free or less than $10/month.

Come out for this great hands on presentation to discuss and learn more about some of the great tools out there to get a startup off the ground.

About David Stiebel

David Stiebel was born and raised in the Detroit suburbs, and went to MIT for his undergrad, where he got a Bachelors in Math with computer science.  In addition to honing his tech and engineering skills, he also became interested in business and finance, and took a job as an Associate Analyst at Bain Consulting in Chicago after graduating. After two years with Bain, he moved on and lived in Israel for a year, before returning to the Detroit area to build a new venture with an old family friend.

Last year, they pivoted and launched PawnGuru (http://www.pawnguru.com/), which they are currently focused on running and growing.

events.name: Michigan Google Developers DevFest 2015
events.description:
Join us for a full day of Android and Google technologies! Check out the event website for the schedule of events and more details: michigandevfest.com

Then head over to purchase a ticket. ($50 for Professionals, $25 for Students)

PLEARE NOTE: This event requires that you purchase a ticket. An RSVP on Meetup is not sufficient.

events.name: What's New in Android M - Live Stream Event from Google
events.description:
Join us for a two-hour live-streamed developer event, wherever you are; home, office, school. You will be able to test the new Android M Developer Preview announced at Google I/O and ask the Googlers who built it.

What do I need to be part of this event? It's simple:

1. Computer with a working Android M development environment.

2. Internet connection that can handle streamed video.

3. Your existing Android app, if you have one.

4. A Google+ account, if you want to ask questions.

What does this event look like?

You will be able to connect to a live video stream. Our Android experts, Chet Haase, Dan Sandler, Adam Powell, will start with a short introduction about what's new in Android. Then you will be able to submit your questions on Google+. The experts will pick questions and answer them in the video stream.

Do I have to register?

Yes, please register at https://bit.ly/newandroidhack to attend this event. That way we can send you the link to the live-stream.

events.name: A Discussion on Android Security with Gilad Pagi
events.description:
A Discussion on Android Security

As a popular open source operating system, Android faces a great security challenge. It must act as a secure platform while revealing its code to the public eyes. Therefore, Android implements various security concepts and mechanism. In this talk we will go over the main security concepts and demonstrate the implementation:

• Android sandboxing.
• Permission architecture.
• Application packaging and signing.
• Shell access capabilities.
• Implication of “rooting” a device

About Gilad Pagi

Gilad Pagi is a summa cum laude graduate of the Technion - Israel Institute of Technology. Gilad acquired his B.S in Math, and B.S + M.S in Engineering before joining a research and development team, first as an engineer and then as an R&D team leader. After seven years, Gilad moved to Michigan and found “GP Group” - a cyber technology consulting company. He is currently pursuing his PhD in Mathematics at the University of Michigan Ann Arbor.

events.name: AngularJS Trick or Treat with Aady Sridhar
events.description:
AngularJS Trick or Treat

Interested in AngularJS? Join the Detroit Google Developers Group as we learn the basics of AngularJS led by Aady Sridhar.

In this discussion, Aady will cover:

• The basics of AngularJS and how an AngularJS app works 

•  AngularJS basic terminologies 

• How to setup a simple AngularJS app 

• Angular back bone(Angular Routing, Directives, Services and Filters) 

•  Simple real world application examples including: 

• Fetching data from server side 

•  Sorting and Filtering of tables 

• Building Custom Filters Built in Angular 

• Filters and their usage in real work applications

• AngularJS Forms and validations A•  AngularJS ng-repeat and ng-forms Checkbox and Radio Buttons in AngularJS 

About Aady Sridhar

Aadhithya Sridhar (Aady) has been a Web Developer at Title Source in downtown Detroit for the past 5 years. He holds Bachelor degrees in BioTechnology and Computer Science and a Masters degree in Computer Science. He has a passion for programming and learning new things and has applied this to his learning of AngularJS. His favorite quote is:

"Most good programmers do programming not because they expect to get paid or get adulation by the public, but because it is fun to program." - Linus Torvalds 

PLEASE NOTE: Unfortunately we can not validate parking for this event.

events.name: An Intro to developing for Google Cardboard with Unity
events.description:
An Intro to Unity and Google Cardboard by Don Ward

Google Cardboard has been around since Google I/O 2014. It is by far the most affordable, and possibly most clever VR viewer out there today. To develop for Google Cardboard, the popular 3d game engine, Unity, is used. 

Come join us as we cover the basics of developing in Unity for Google Cardboard. This introduction will cover:

• What is Unity and how to develop 3d apps using it.

• How to develop for Google Cardboard in a Unity project.

• Best practices for developing for Google Cardboard.

About Don Ward

Don Ward has been involved in the local software developer community for the past five years helping organize such events as 1DevDay Detroit 2011 and 2012, MobiDevDay 2010, and CloudDevDay 2010. Currently Don Ward is an avid Google technology enthusiast and enjoys leading one of the mobile teams at Quicken Loans during the day.

events.name: Rescheduled - Show & Tell Meeting
events.description:
RESCHEDULED FROM JAN 12, 2016  - The Detroit Google Developer's Group is trying something new to start the year off. We have lined up a number of local presenters with some cool projects that they want to demo.

This is your traditional Show & Tell style meeting with projects using some of the following technologies:

• AngularJS 

• Elixir

• The Nymi Band 

• Unity and Google Cardboard

• Developing for Embedded Devices   

Join us for a night of cool demo's by our members and some great networking.

events.name: Android Design Patterns with Godfrey Nolan
events.description:
Come join the Detroit Google Developers Group for a discussion on Android Design Patterns with Godfrey Nolan

Android apps all too often grow quickly into hard to maintain apps.  With a little more focus on architecture, developers can extend the life of their code considerably making it easier to add new features and easier for other developers to maintain your code.  Android Design Patterns looks at the emerging architectures to keep your Android apps clean.  In this meetup we take an in depth look at the MVC, MVP and MVVM design patterns using real-world examples.

About Godfrey

Godfrey Nolan is founder and president of RIIS LLC, a mobile development firm in Troy.  He is also author of "Agile Android", “Bulletproof Android”, “Android Best Practices”, “Decompiling Android” and “Decompiling Java.” Godfrey has spoken at DroidCon, AnDevcon as well as JavaOne, ASP-Connections, VSLive, Codemash, Code PaLOUsa, 1DevDay and many local Java and .Net user groups on a wide range of topics such as Continuous Integration, Unit Testing and mobile security.

*** PLEASE NOTE: Unfortunately we can not validate parking for this event ***

events.name: Google Cloud Platform Codelab
events.description:
With the Google Cloud Platform Global Community Conference at the end of March we will be walking through some of what was presented and doing some self-paced code labs. 

While we are not experts on the Google Cloud Platform, we will hope to facilitate a good night of learning and networking for all who attend. Remember to bring your laptop!

events.name: Michigan DevFest 2016
events.description:
The Detroit Google Developers Group (GDG), working with the Ann Arbor and Toledo GDG's are proud to present the 4th annual Michigan DevFest.

Join us for a day of learning and networking in downtown Detroit. With sessions on Android, Polymer, Clean Architecture and Prototyping without Code, we have a great day planned for you!

Breakfast and lunch will be provided, and there will be great prizes raffled off throughout the day.

Registration is required for entry, and info and ticket sales can be here: http://michigandevfest.com/

events.name: Ask Firebase: Live Google+ Hangout
events.description:
Join us for a two-hour live streamed Google developer event from wherever you are. 

On May 26th at 3:00 PM PDT (6:00 PM EDT) you will be able to ask James Tamplin, co-founder of Firebase and Magnus Hyttsten, Developer Advocate questions about Firebase LIVE! Make sure to start posting your questions today with #AskFirebaseLive on Google+. 

Register at https://goo.gl/UK3uJ8﻿

events.name: Android Dependency Injection with Dagger 2
events.description:
Dagger is a fully static, compile-time dependency injection framework for both Java and Android. It is an adaptation of an earlier version created by Square and now maintained by Google. Dagger aims to address many of the development and performance issues that have plagued reflection-based solutions. 

What is dependency injection?

Dependency injection is a concept which is not limited to Java. But we will look at dependency injection from a Java point of view. The general concept behind dependency injection is called Inversion of Control. According to this concept a class should not configure its dependencies statically but should be configured from the outside.

*** PLEASE NOTE: Unfortunately we can not validate parking for this event ***

Dhiwakar Mani is a Sr Mobile Application Developer @ Title Source, Detroit. Dhiwakar Mani has been developing and architecting native Android apps with passion for last 8+ years. He is passionate about technology, mobile and helping people become their best.

Dhiwakar Mani loves to play Cricket and enjoy travelling around the world.

events.name: Let's Meetup and see the work of newly-minted developers!
events.description: Grand Circus, a coding bootcamp in downtown Detroit, is hosting a Demo Day to showcase the final presentations of their most recent Front-End and Java cohorts. There will be light appetizers, great networking, and a great opportunity to see the applications developed by these enthusiastic new coders!

events.name: Show & Tell - Round 2
events.description:
To kick off the school year, we would like to host another Show & Tell night featuring some of our local talent. 

Every software developer we have ever met has some cool side project that they work on. It typically uses a technology they are passionate about and when they explain and show it - their passion for what they have created oozes out. 

For September, we want to host a night where you get to show off your cool side projects. 

Do you have a software cool project you are willing to show the world? Extra bonus points if it uses a cool Google Technology. Reach out to myself or Kris Peach and we will add you to the agenda for the evening.

events.name: Android Accessibility with David Truxall
events.description:
Android Accessibility with Dave Truxall

Accessibility is often an afterthought when developing apps of any kind, yet if your app is not inclusive, you are losing a large percentage of your potential market. In addition to lost market share, there is also a potential legal aspect of accessibility if you are building applications for government organizations. Section 508 mandates specific types of accessibility features in your app, and the rules for apps are different than the rules for web sites. This session covers the Section 508 rules for apps and demonstrates tools and coding techniques which enable your application to embrace disabled users.

About David Truxall 

A long time resident of metro Detroit, Dr. Truxall has been slinging code for a living since 1995, working with enterprise web technologies, modeling business processes, and building public web sites and mobile apps for some of the largest organizations in North America. Always an enthusiast for troubleshooting systems, Trux has rescued numerous troubled applications and improved their performance. Co-author of the book "Android Best Practices", he speaks at local conferences and user groups. Currently Trux is working in mobility at Hewlett Packard Enterprise, bringing mobile apps and their supporting systems to the public sector.

events.name: Introduction to Kotlin
events.description:
Getting started with Android and Kotlin. Simple Kotlin application for Android using Android Studio

*** PLEASE NOTE: Unfortunately we can not validate parking for this event ***

Dhiwakar Mani is a Sr Mobile Application Developer @ Title Source, Detroit. Dhiwakar Mani has been developing and architecting native Android apps with passion for last 8+ years. He is passionate about technology, mobile and helping people become their best.

Dhiwakar Mani loves to play Cricket and enjoy travelling around the world.

events.name: Build Mobile Apps Users Want to Use with David Truxall
events.description:
Build Apps Users Want to Use
It's an unfortunate truth that most users don't stick with new apps very long. Every developer is looking for the one secret that will make users love their app. Sadly, there is no secret but there are a number of techniques available to developers that can make an app more compelling for users. These techniques actually focus on user psychology and even physiology, and as a developer you should employ these ideas when creating an app. This session covers three separate techniques rooted in psychology you can implement to make your app awesome and keep your users coming back.

About David Truxall
A long time resident of metro Detroit, Dr. Truxall has been slinging code for a living since 1995, working with enterprise web technologies, modeling business processes, and building public web sites and mobile apps for some of the largest organizations in North America. Always an enthusiast for troubleshooting systems, Trux has rescued numerous troubled applications and improved their performance. Co-author of the book "Android Best Practices", he speaks at local conferences and user groups. Currently Trux is working in mobility at Hewlett Packard Enterprise, bringing mobile apps and their supporting systems to the public sector.

PLEASE NOTE: Unfortunately we can not validate parking for this event.

events.name: The 5th Annual Michigan GDG DevFest
events.description:
A ticket is required for this event. Early bird tickets are on sale till April 2 for $25/student and $50/professional. 

The Detroit, and Ann Arbor Google Developer Groups are teaming up to bring you our 5th annual Michigan GDG DevFest on Saturday, April 22nd, 2017 in Grand Circus' offices in downtown Detroit.

This year we are excited to have great speakers like:

•  Dave Mehi from Google discussing the Google Cloud Platform 

•  David Smith from SPLT discussing why SPLT went with React Native to build their Android App 

•  Kyle Paul from Phisionary explaining how to use Firebase in all of your projects

Included with ticket price is breakfast, lunch, snack and a great day of learning and networking with developers from the local software development community.

Want to buy a ticket? Head over here: https://goo.gl/0LLSgk

Want more info? Head over here: https://gdgmichigandevfest.com

events.name: Let's dive into TensorFlow!
events.description:
Join us for an evening of learning Google's Open Source Machine Learning Library - TensorFlow. We will be checking out some resources on TensorFlow as well as working through some codelabs.

We will be networking from 6:30pm to 7pm and then will start promptly at 7pm.

events.name: Bluetooth Low Energy on Android: Top Tips for the Tricky Bits
events.description:
Bluetooth Low Energy on Android: Top Tips for the Tricky Bits

Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) powers the Internet of Things (IoT): smart watches, smart bulbs, and smart cars all use it for short-range communication. Now that 90% of Android consumer devices and 100% of Android Things devices run software that supports BLE, there’s never been a better time for Android developers to jump into the rapidly-growing IoT ecosystem and start building their own companion apps or custom smart devices. 

Unfortunately, Android’s Bluetooth stack has a well-deserved reputation for being difficult to work with. The documentation is patchy, the API abstractions are leaky, and the stack itself is unreliable. Stuart has worked through all these challenges while building a pro audio app at the start of 2017, and now is sharing his story to save you time. 

The beginning of this talk will cover BLE basics. The remainder will showcase code samples and strategies for tackling the quirks of the Android Bluetooth stack. No prior experience with BLE is required to enjoy this talk. You’ll leave excited to tinker with BLE on Android and equipped with a roadmap and toolkit to help you navigate the nasty parts. 

About Stuart Kent

Stuart is software developer with 3.5 years' mobile experience. He currently work at Detroit Labs creating native Android and iOS apps for national and international brands in the utilities, QSR, automotive, and pro audio industries. Before becoming a developer, he taught college and earned a Ph.D. in Applied Math. Likes: Enums. Dislikes: dogmatism.

events.name: Solar Power and Google's Project Sunroof by Dave Strenski
events.description:
Solar Power and Google's Project Sunroof by Dave Strenski

This presentation will review the basics of solar power, including how it works, how it's attached to a home or business, and the economics of solar power. Dave will also review some of Ypsilanti's current successes including the installation of 800kW in the Highland Cemetery, 50kW on the roof of the local Fire Station (SolarYpsi.org/FireHouseArticle.html), and Ypsi's national GoldSolSmart award (SolarYpsi.org/SolSmartAward.html) from the SolarFoundation - the first and only in Michigan. 

Finally the talk will cover how to use Google's Project SunRoof (google.com/get/sunroof) to encourage more and larger solar installations in the City. 

Unable to attend the presentation? Check out these on line resources: 

• SolarYpsi.org/GoogleVideo.html

• SolarYpsi.org/TEDxVideo.html

• SolarYpsi.org/AerialVideos.html 

• SolarYpsi.org/SolarTodayArticle.html

About Dave Stenski

Dave has degrees in surveying, civil, and mechanical engineering and is currently a principal engineer at Cray Inc (cray.com). Cray is a company that designs and manufactures High Performance Computing systems. As a hobby, Dave plays with solar power and is the founder of SolarYpsi.org, which has helped the City of Ypsilanti go from zero solar power in 2005 to over a megawatt of solar power today.

events.name: Machine Learning - Bolting it all Together by Don Ward
events.description:
Machine Learning - Bolting it all Together

For this month's session, Don Ward will be starting from the ground up and explaining some of the basic concepts in Machine Learning.

Starting from Linear Regression, Logistic Regression and moving onto Neural Networks, this session should provide a good foundation for those interested in learning more about Machine Learning. Many of the concepts presented will be taken from the Stanford Course on Machine Learning in Coursera (see here (https://www.coursera.org/learn/machine-learning/home/welcome)).

Are you a Machine Learning expert? This will be an informal style presentation, and we would love to have you join us and share with the community some of your hard earned knowledge.

Unfortunately we can not validate parking for the meeting.

events.name: Google Cloud Study Jam
events.description:
Google Cloud Study Jam

The Detroit Google Developers is excited to host our first ever Google Cloud Study Jam!

What is a Google Cloud Study Jam?
Cloud Study Jams are Google sponsored community-run study groups to learn more about Cloud Computing and using Google’s Cloud offerings. Google provides each attendee access to QwikLabs (online course training) during the Study Jam to work through and learn about cloud computing as well as Google Cloud offerings. A Study Jam session differs from our typical monthly presentations that the Detroit Google Developers Group hosts. Study jams are self-paced sessions where a bunch of developers meet and work through some exercises and courses.

What will you learn?
Specifically you will learn the fundamentals of the Google Cloud Platform, how to run containers on it and how to use the platform for data engineering. You will get free access to the labs ($70+ value). No need to create a Google Cloud Platform account or register with a credit card. More details below:
• You will learn how to some of the Google Cloud offerings in a self-paced course.
• Learn how to set up development and production environments in the Cloud.
• Learn how Docker and Kubernetes work, or learn how to process Big Data in the Cloud.
• Get access to Qwiklabs.com, a Google training tool, free of charge (a $70+ value).
• Get Google-hosted badges like this for their online profiles, to show potential employers what they know about Cloud computing.

*****PLEASE NOTE: Please bring your own laptop computer. We can not provide computers to work through the labs with. Free Wifi will be available. *****

Unfortunately we can not validate parking for the meeting.

events.name: Google TensorFlow DevSummit Extended & ML Study Jam 2018
events.description:
Google TensorFlow DevSummit Extended & ML Study Jam 2018

The Detroit Google Developers is excited to host our first ever Google TensorFlow DevSummit Extended & ML Study Jam 2018! This event will be a combination of a Machine Learning Study Jam and summary of the TensorFlow DevSummit on March 30, 2018 (see here: https://www.tensorflow.org/dev-summit/)

*****PLEASE NOTE: Please bring your own laptop computer. We can not provide computers to work through the labs with. Free Wifi will be available. *****

events.name: Build Google Assistant Actions
events.description:
Build Actions for Your Community with Google Assistant
Join us as we learn how to build actions using Google Assistant.

Agenda:
9:00am - 9:30am - Networking
9:30am - Intro
9:40am - Building Conversational Experiences with Actions on Google
10:10am - Conversational Design Intro
10:45am - Break

12:00pm - Create Actions for your Community (Team Activity)

PLEASE NOTE: You will need to bring your laptop.

events.name: Counting Sheep with Drones and AI by Godfrey Nolan
events.description: This class is a hands-on guide to adding AI to your drone’s mobile app to count sheep in a field. Using Google’s Tensorflow we can relatively quickly add trained models to any Android app. After a brief overview of machine learning and how to use machine learning in Android apps, you’ll see how to process the video from a drone app so we can use the AI to literally count how many sheep there are in the farmer’s field. You’ll see how we trained the model, implemented the app and tested it in the real world.

events.name: Flutter Study Jam
events.description:
Flutter is Google’s mobile app SDK for crafting high-quality native interfaces on iOS and Android in record time. Flutter works with existing code, is used by developers and organizations around the world, and is free and open source.

Want to get started on building Flutter apps?

Join us for our Flutter Study Jam! Together we'll work through Flutter Udacity Course prepared by Google instructors. You will be able to get hands-on experience with Flutter and build a Flutter app while learning the fundamentals..

There will be second meetup to continue this study jam in October. Keep a look out for that event soon.

Bring a laptop! The course will run on all of the latest versions of the popular browsers. For the best experience, the laptop should have Flutter installed on it prior to starting the study jam to save time. Windows/Linux/Mac would all be fine. Check out : https://flutter.io/get-started/install/

Agenda:
7:00pm: Flutter Udacity Course Introduction
7:10pm: Udacity Course Lesson 1
9:00pm: Event ends

events.name: Flutter Study Jam - Part 2
events.description:
Flutter is Google’s mobile app SDK for crafting high-quality native interfaces on iOS and Android in record time. Flutter works with existing code, is used by developers and organizations around the world, and is free and open source.

Want to get started on building Flutter apps?

Join us for our Flutter Study Jam! Together we'll work through Flutter Udacity Course prepared by Google instructors. You will be able to get hands-on experience with Flutter and build a Flutter app while learning the fundamentals..

There will be second meetup to continue this study jam in October. Keep a look out for that event soon.

Bring a laptop! The course will run on all of the latest versions of the popular browsers. For the best experience, the laptop should have Flutter installed on it prior to starting the study jam to save time. Windows/Linux/Mac would all be fine. Check out : https://flutter.io/get-started/install/

Agenda:

7:00pm: Udacity Course Lesson 2

events.name: Michigan DevFest - Tickets on Sale Now!
events.description:
The Detroit, Ann Arbor and Windsor Google Developer Groups are teaming up to bring you the Michigan GDG DevFest on November 10, 2018 in Grand Circus’ offices in downtown Detroit. This is our 6th annual DevFest and you will not want to miss it.

YOU NEED TO PURCHASE A TICKET TO ATTEND. Tickets and more details can be found here: https://www.michigandevfest.com

events.name: Holiday Hangout at Calexico
events.description:
Google is sponsoring a Holiday Hangout for the Detroit GDG. Join us at Calexico in downtown Detroit for a evening of food and drinks. We will be raffling off a few Google Home Hubs as well.

Seating will be limited to first come first serve, so sign up asap.

events.name: Google Kubernetes Engine with Gary Coburn, Google Cloud Customer Engineer
events.description:
For our February meeting, Google will be hosting us in their Detroit Office for a presentation on Google Kubernetes Engine.

Kubernetes Engine is a managed, production-ready environment for deploying containerized applications. It brings our latest innovations in developer productivity, resource efficiency, automated operations, and open source flexibility to accelerate your time to market.

Launched in 2015, Kubernetes Engine builds on Google’s experience of running services like Gmail and YouTube in containers for over 12 years. Kubernetes Engine allows you to get up and running with Kubernetes in no time, by completely eliminating the need to install, manage, and operate your own Kubernetes clusters.

Gary Coburn, Google Cloud Customer Engineer will take the group through Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) and GKE Local.

~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^
The Schedule For the Eventing is below,

6:00pm - 7:00pm - Doors open for registration, networking
and food. Food and beverages will be available, free of charge.

7:00pm - 7:45pm - Kubernetes Presentation by Gary Coburn, Google Cloud Customer Engineer

7:45pm - 8:00pm - Break.

8:00pm - 9:00pm - Kubernetes Demonstration and Guided walk
through. Gary Coburn, Google Cloud Customer Engineer will take the group through a practical real-world example of using standard deployment tools to provision and deploy your first application.

Using the tools demonstrated you’ll be able to do your first deployment to GKE and have an automated procedure which you’ll be able to replicate in day to day life.

~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^
Parking and Logistics

We can validate parking for those that use the Henry Street Garage, refer to the address below,

The Henry Street Garage
128 W Fisher Service Dr,
Detroit, MI 48201

Once you have parked you will need to enter the arena using the Google entrance which is located on the south side of the building (head north-east from the garage), you will see a large Google sign above the entrance.

LCA security will ask you to pass through a metal detector. Once you are cleared, you will be greeted by a Google employee who will help you find your name tag and then direct you to the 4th floor where the event will be held.
~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^

events.name: TensorFlow Dev Summit Recap
events.description:
On March 6th and 7th, 2019, Google hosted the TensorFlow Dev Summit in Sunnyvale, CA. They live streamed the event and will be providing video's of the event.

Join us on March 18, 2019 as the Detroit GDG hosts a recap of the TensorFlow Dev Summit. We will be covering news from the Summit, and what impacts this may have on the overall use of TensorFlow.

Additionally, we will be sharing how to get TensorFlow up and running on a multitude of devices including mobile phones, IoT devices and your within your favourite web browser.

We will be providing dinner as well as swag and prize giveaways.

~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^
The Schedule For the Evening is below,

6:30pm - 7:00pm - Doors open for registration, networking
and food. Food and beverages will be available, free of charge.

7:00pm - 7:45pm - Watch parts of the Dev Summit Keynote along with a recap of the TensorFlow Summit by Don Ward

7:45pm - 8:00pm - Break.

8:00pm - 8:30pm - Impact of announcements at the Summit by Don Ward.

~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^~^
